intro: Cyperus badius var. minor, commonly known as the narrowleaf sedges, is a flowering plant in the sedge family (Cyperaceae). It is a perennial herb that typically grows in wet or seasonally flooded soils, often found in marshes, wetlands, and along the edges of water bodies. The plant has slender, grass-like leaves and produces small, three-sided spikelets that are often clustered at the tips of the stems. It is characterized by its narrow, linear leaves and a compact growth habit. This variant is often used in ecological restoration projects due to its ability to stabilize soil and provide habitat for aquatic and terrestrial organisms.
